article.author_comments:
I am pleased to submit an original research article entitled “The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study” for consideration for publication in OpenHeart Journal.
Sacubitril-valsartan (ARNI) has shown a supplemental benefit in terms of both survival and hospitalization compared to enalapril and, therefore, it was included in the ESC guideline flow- chart for HFrEF outpatients . This prospective study suggests a possible mechanism underlying the positive effect on prognosis and mortality shown by the sacubitril-valsartan therapy in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Our results identify CPET parameters and Peak Atrial Longitudinal Strain (PALS) as a more sensitive parameter than the traditional diastolic function measurements in detecting the effect of the ARNI therapy. This study highlights the importance of the ARNY therapy in the clinical management of HFrEF patients. It also outlines the importance of a multi-parameter evaluation of this setting, considering clinical, functional, traditional and advanced echocardiographic parameters.
This manuscript has not been published and is not under consideration for publication elsewhere. We have no conflicts of interest to disclose.
Thank you for your consideration!
Sincerely,

editor.comments: Meier, Pascal, pascal.meier@uclh.nhs.uk merged with this user on 19-Dec-2013 by Fountain, Lindsey Meier, Pascal, pascal.meier@ksgr.ch merged with this user on 27-Mar-2020 by Fountain, Lindsey Meier, Pascal, pascalmeier@gmx.ch merged with this user on 27-Mar-2020 by Fountain, Lindsey

file.file_caption: Caption : Figure 1: Measurement of Peak Atrial Longitudinal Strain (PALS) using Speckle Tracking echocardiography from apical 4-chamber view in a representative patient with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction at baseline (left) and after 12 months of ARNI therapy (right).

recommendation_comments.comment:
Longstanding article we have had under our review which has gone 2x revisions.
Its an interesting small study looking at ventricular and atrial morphological changes following ARNI therapy. Whilst prior reviewers have highlighted some limitations in terms of small sample and limited findings, we have had discussions with the author to revise the manuscript accordingly to point out the fact that this is a pilot hypothesis-generating study.
Therefore, when considered like so, it could be an interesting article for our readers and may generate citations in this field

article.abstract: Background: The indisputable benefits of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) therapy in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) has raised an interest around the pathophysiological changes associated with this novel therapy. The aim of the present study is to define the impact over time of the ARNI therapy on biochemical, echocardiographic and functional parameters in HFrEF patients. Methods: Twenty-four consecutive patients affected by HFrEF eligible for therapy with sacubitril-valsartan according to current guidelines were enrolled from January 2019 to January 2020. Clinical, laboratory and echocardiographic data – including speckle tracking analysis (STE), as well as cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) – were obtained at baseline and at 6 and 12 months of follow-up. Results: Left ventricular ejection fraction significantly and constantly increased at the 6- and 12-month follow-up (from 31.3±4% to 36.2±7% and 39.2±8%, <0.001), while the E/e’ ratio significantly decreased at 6 months (11.6±7.7 vs 9,3±5.6, p <0.05), remaining stable at 12 months. An improvement in Peak Atrial Longitudinal Strain (PALS), as evaluated by STE, was demonstrated, and was statistically significant both at 6 and 12 months (from 15.8±4.9% to 21.9±5.2 at 6 months and 23.5± 6.2 at 12 months; p <0.0001 and p = 0.01, respectively). At CPET, a progressive and significant increase in peak oxygen consumption was observed at 6 and 12 months (from 13.8±3.6 mL/min/kg to 15.6±3.6 mL/min/kg, p <0.05 at 6 months of follow-up and to 15.7±3.7 mL/min/kg, p <0.05 at 12 months). Conclusion: The benefit of the ARNI therapy appeared in the first six month, and was sustained at 12 months. Among the diastolic function parameters, PALS was more sensitive to ARNI therapy than the traditional ones. Peak oxygen consumption (peak VO2) significantly improved after 6 and 12 months of therapy with ARNI.

Thank you for choosing ##JOURNAL_NAME## to publish your research.

At BMJ, we are committed to supporting the publication of good clinical research. The first journal is not always the right option, so if unfortunately your paper is rejected, our Transfer Service gives you the option to automatically submit to an alternate BMJ journal of your choice. To find out more about how this service works visit our Author Hub transfer page.

Do you want to benefit from our Transfer Service?
Choose your preferred alternate BMJ journal in the drop-down list, go through the checklist below and our team will take care of the rest.

- Make sure that your article is relevant for the scope of the other journal. Browse all BMJ Journals or contact our Transfer Editor (mrichards@bmj.com) if you would like more information on what alternate journal would be relevant for your research.
- Confirm that you have the agreement of all other authors.

BMJ Journals have differing publishing policies, and papers accepted for publication may be subject to an Article Processing Charge (APC). Waivers and discounts are offered in certain circumstances. For more information on APCs and discounts visit the publication charges section in our Author Hub.

If you choose to transfer your article to BMJ Case Reports, you should be aware that you will need to have a Fellowship subscription to the journal. For more information please visit https://casereports.bmj.com/pages/fellowships/

*This is an optional service - you do not have to select any other journals. If you would like more information please contact the editorial office at ##EMAIL_CONTACT_ADMIN_CENTER_EMAIL##.

If you want to include illustrative material that contains material within or belongs to someone else in your article, you must either: a) obtain permission from the owner first and pay any required fees; b) follow the required processes for reuse in line with the STM Permission Guidelines (where applicable); or c) be able to rely on a copyright exception for the use. Illustrative material can include, but is not limited to - brands, diagrams, figures, graphs, images, photos, pictures, or tables.

Permission must cover any way that BMJ distributes the article, through subscriptions and via third parties (such as document delivery organisations, aggregators, repositories and Pubmed Central).

You must also confirm that you have included a copyright notice and/or acknowledgement(s) identifying the source and rights holder (and as required by the rights holder) within the illustrative material(s).

article.notes:
• Please include the corresponding author's phone number.
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript an Ethics Approval disclosure statement that the study obtained ethics approval (or a statement that it was not required and why), including the name of the ethics committee(s) or institutional review board(s), the number/ID of the approval(s), and a statement that participants gave informed consent before taking part.
• Please include a contributorship statement that declares each author’s contribution to the paper according to the ICMJE guidelines for authorship in the unblinded manuscript. http://www.bmj.com/about-bmj/resources-authors/article-submission/authorship-contributorship
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript a conflict of interest statement that describes any competing interests any authors have (or a statement that there aren’t any).
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript a funding disclosure statement that describes the funding for your paper (or a statement that it was not funded).;

openhrt-2020-001386.R2 entitled "The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study.," with Dr. Spera as submitting author, has been accepted to Open Heart.
Please complete the production checklist for this manuscript as soon as possible.
Kind regards,
Christine Janssen-Seijkens Open Heart Editorial Office info.openheart@bmj.com

email_sent.subject: openhrt-2020-001386.R2 - Thank you for your review - A decision has been made
email_sent.body:
@@date to be populated upon sending@@,
openhrt-2020-001386.R2 Title: The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study.
Dear Reviewer,
We are very grateful for the time you have generously given to help us ensure that Open Heart publishes high quality, well-written and accessible research. We could not do this without the advice and expertise of our reviewers.
The decision on the above article was: Accept Comments to the Author collated during the peer review process are below:
Reviewer(s') Comments to Author:
If you have any questions or feedback, please do not hesitate to contact the Editorial Office.
Kind regards, Christine Janssen-Seijkens, Open Heart Editorial office

Dear Arif,
Recently, you chose Reviewers for Manuscript ID openhrt-2020-001386.R2, entitled "The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study.." The manuscript has received the required number of reviews and is now ready for your recommendation.
You can click on the link below to send your recommendation: https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/openheart?URL_MASK=8dff01ea1d75479ba971bcdd411e6d61
With best wishes, Pascal

send_date.time_zone: (GMT) Greenwich Mean Time : Dublin, Edinburgh, Lisbon, London

email_sent.subject: Open Heart - Manuscript ID openhrt-2020-001386.R2
email_sent.body:
02-Jul-2021
Dear Dr. Spera:
Your manuscript entitled "The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study." has been successfully submitted online and is presently being given full consideration for publication in Open Heart.
Your manuscript ID is openhrt-2020-001386.R2.
Please mention the above manuscript ID in all future correspondence or when calling the office for questions. If there are any changes in your street address or e-mail address, please log in to ScholarOne Manuscripts at https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/openheart and edit your user information as appropriate.
Please check that all author names are correctly entered as this will be the name displayed in any PubMed search.
You can also view the status of your manuscript at any time by checking your Author Center after logging in to https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/openheart.
Any individuals listed as co-authors on this manuscript are copied into this submission confirmation email. If you believe that you have received this email in error, please contact the Editorial Office.
Thank you for submitting your manuscript to Open Heart.
Kind regards,
Editor in Chief, Open Heart
P.s. What did you think of the article submission process? At BMJ, we constantly strive to improve our services for authors. We value your feedback and we'd be grateful if could take 5 minutes to fill out our short survey. Your responses will remain confidential and you won’t be identified in any results.
Please click on this link to access the survey: https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/r/VMXSQGP
We are constantly trying to find ways of improving our peer review system and continually monitor processes and methods by including article submissions and reviewers’ reports in our research. If you do not wish your paper or review entered into our peer review research programme, please let us know by emailing papersadmin@bmj.com as soon as possible.

send_date.time_zone: (GMT) Greenwich Mean Time : Dublin, Edinburgh, Lisbon, London

email_sent.subject: Open Heart - openhrt-2020-001386.R2 has been returned for author attention
email_sent.body:
06-Jul-2021
Dear Dr. Spera:
Thank you for your submission to Open Heart. However, your manuscript, openhrt-2020-001386.R2, entitled "The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study." has been returned to you to address the following issues before it can be assigned to the Editor.
Please see the point(s) below regarding your manuscript, which need your action:
• Please include the corresponding author's phone number.
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript an Ethics Approval disclosure statement that the study obtained ethics approval (or a statement that it was not required and why), including the name of the ethics committee(s) or institutional review board(s), the number/ID of the approval(s), and a statement that participants gave informed consent before taking part.
• Please include a contributorship statement that declares each author’s contribution to the paper according to the ICMJE guidelines for authorship in the unblinded manuscript. http://www.bmj.com/about-bmj/resources-authors/article-submission/authorship-contributorship
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript a conflict of interest statement that describes any competing interests any authors have (or a statement that there aren’t any).
• Please include in your unblinded manuscript a funding disclosure statement that describes the funding for your paper (or a statement that it was not funded).
Your paper will be found under "unsubmitted manuscripts" in your Author centre where you will be able to complete your submission and re-submit the manuscript for consideration of publication.
You may contact the Editorial Office if you have further questions at info.openheart@bmj.com
Kind regards,
Naomi Spicer Open Heart Editorial Office

send_date.time_zone: (GMT) Greenwich Mean Time : Dublin, Edinburgh, Lisbon, London

Kind regards,
Editor in Chief, Open Heart
P.s. What did you think of the article submission process? At BMJ, we constantly strive to improve our services for authors. We value your feedback and we'd be grateful if could take 5 minutes to fill out our short survey. Your responses will remain confidential and you won’t be identified in any results.
Please click on this link to access the survey: https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/r/VMXSQGP
We are constantly trying to find ways of improving our peer review system and continually monitor processes and methods by including article submissions and reviewers’ reports in our research. If you do not wish your paper or review entered into our peer review research programme, please let us know by emailing papersadmin@bmj.com as soon as possible.

email_sent.subject: openhrt-2020-001386.R2 now in your Associate Editor Center after minor revision
email_sent.body:
26-Jul-2021
Dear Arif,
the revised manuscript openhrt-2020-001386.R2 entitled "The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study." with Dr. Lucia Spera as contact author has been assigned to you and is currently sitting in your Associate Editor Center at https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/openheart.
Please look at the revised manuscript and decide if the authors have adequately addressed the reviewers' and editors' comments. If so, please change the number of required reviews to zero and make your recommendation. If you think that the revised manuscript needs to be reviewed again, please invite the original reviewers and/or select new reviewers as appropriate by 29-Jul-2021. If, for any reason, you are unable to serve as Associate Editor for this manuscript, please notify me immediately so that I can reassign it.
You can begin work on this manuscript by clicking on this link; https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/openheart?URL_MASK=5fa1626312e144d0ae15bbd8cb66002a
With best wishes, Pascal

email_sent.subject: Your submission to Open Heart has been accepted
email_sent.body:
02-Aug-2021 openhrt-2020-001386.R2 - The effect of the angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor on the functional capacity and left ventricular and atrial myocardial function in patients with systolic heart failure: a pilot study.
Dear Dr. Spera:
We are pleased to accept your article for publication in Open Heart.
Within 2-3 working days, you will receive an email with payment options and instructions from BMJ's e-commerce partner, Copyright Clearance Center. You will be able to choose either to pay by credit card or invoice. If you are not making the payment yourself, you may forward the email to the person or organisation that will be paying on your behalf. Your article will not be processed by production until you have paid the article processing charge or requested an invoice. For more details on open access publication please visit our Author Hub: https://authors.bmj.com/open-access/.
Please note, that if your institution is part of one of BMJ’s Publish and Read or prepay agreements your request for funding will be automatically processed based on this acceptance and you will only receive an email accepting or denying your funding request. To find out if your institution is part of a Publish and Read or prepay agreement visit BMJ’s open access agreements page: https://authors.bmj.com/open-access/institutional-programme/.
Once payment is confirmed and your article is sent to Production, copyediting and typesetting will be completed. We will email you a proof to check via our online tool usually within 10-15 days of this time; please check your junk mail folder.
The proof is your opportunity to check for typesetting errors and the completeness and accuracy of the text; including author names and affiliations, tables and figures; including legends, numerical, mathematical, or other scientific expressions. We ask that you only make minor corrections at this stage. Please provide any comments within 48 hours. There will be no further opportunities to make corrections prior to publication.
See https://authors.bmj.com/after-submitting/accepted/ for more information about what to expect once your article has been accepted.
We publish most articles online in their final form around three weeks after acceptance. See https://authors.bmj.com/after-submitting/online-publication/ for more information about online publication. BMJ will deposit your article in all indexes affiliated with the journal.
Any final comments from the reviewer(s) are included at the foot of this email. The comments are for your information only, but in the case of minor requests (e.g. typos) these can be corrected when you receive your proof.
If your article is selected for press release by BMJ’s Press Office you will be informed as soon as possible. Authors are encouraged to provide their Twitter handle, if they have one, at proof checking stage. This will be published on the article alongside your affiliation details. This will also assist our social media team with promotion of your paper when published. More information about how you can best promote your own work is available at https://authors.bmj.com/promote-your-paper/how-to-promote/.
If you have any questions, please contact the Editorial Office.
Thank you for your contribution, and we hope that you will continue to submit to the journal in future.
Kind regards,
Dr. Pascal Meier Editor in Chief, Open Heart
https://openheart.bmj.com/ @Open_HeartBMJ
